featureDescription.name: suggestions
featureDescription.description: An array of the suggested actions to be taken for this anomaly.

featureDescription.name: replacement
featureDescription.description: The text covered by the Anomaly annotation should be replaced with the contents of this feature.

featureDescription.name: certainty
featureDescription.description: A score representing how certain is this suggested action. Usually in [0,1].

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.coref.type.CoreferenceChain
typeDescription.description: Marks the beginning of a chain.

featureDescription.name: first
featureDescription.description: This is the first corefernce link in coreference chain

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.coref.type.CoreferenceLink
typeDescription.description: A link in the coreference chain.

featureDescription.name: next
featureDescription.description: If there is one, it is the next coreference link to the current coreference link

featureDescription.name: referenceType
featureDescription.description: The role or type which the covered text has in the coreference chain.

featureDescription.name: referenceRelation
featureDescription.description: The type of relation between this link and the next link in the chain.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.frequency.tfidf.type.Tfidf
typeDescription.description: Annotates the tf.idf score of a token, stem, or lemma.

featureDescription.name: tfidfValue
featureDescription.description: The tf.idf score.

featureDescription.name: term
featureDescription.description:
The string that was used to compute this tf.idf score. If a stem or lemma was used, the covered text of this annotation does not need to be equal to this string.
This string can be used to construct a vector space with the right terms without having to access the indexes again.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.lexmorph.type.morph.MorphologicalFeatures
typeDescription.description:
Morphological categories that can be attached to tokens.
The features are supposed to match the Universal Dependency v1 features.

featureDescription.name: number
featureDescription.description: Singular/plural

featureDescription.name: case
featureDescription.description: Nouns: nominative, genetiv, dative, ...

featureDescription.name: degree
featureDescription.description: Adjectives: comparative/Superlative

featureDescription.name: tense
featureDescription.description: Verbs: past tense, present tense, future tense, etc.

featureDescription.name: mood
featureDescription.description: Verbs: indicative, imperative, subjunctive

featureDescription.name: voice
featureDescription.description: Verbs: active/passive

featureDescription.name: definiteness
featureDescription.description: Definite or indefinite

featureDescription.name: value
featureDescription.description: The original morphological analysis results as produced by a tool or as recorded in a corpus (if available). If the categories were originally encoded in such a string, the other features are filled by analyzing this string. If the categories were provided separately, e.g. by different attributed in an XML-encoded corpus, this field may remain empty.

featureDescription.name: person
featureDescription.description: Verbs: 1st, 2nd, 3rd person

featureDescription.name: aspect
featureDescription.description: Verbs: perfective, imperfective

featureDescription.name: transitivity
featureDescription.description:
Verbs: transitive/intransitive
@deprecated

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.lexmorph.type.pos.POS
typeDescription.description: The part of speech of a word or a phrase.

featureDescription.name: PosValue
featureDescription.description: Fine-grained POS tag. This is the tag as produced by a POS tagger or obtained from a reader.

featureDescription.name: coarseValue
featureDescription.description: Coarse-grained POS tag. This may be produced by a POS tagger or reader in addition to the fine-grained tag.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.lexmorph.type.pos.tweet.POS_AT
typeDescription.description: at-mention (indicates another user as a recipient of a tweet)

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.lexmorph.type.pos.tweet.POS_DM
typeDescription.description: discourse marker, indications of continuation of a message across multiple tweets

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.metadata.type.MetaDataStringField
typeDescription.description: A general purpose annotation to store document-wide information in the form of arbitrary key-value string pairs.

featureDescription.name: key
featureDescription.description: Name of a metadata field.

featureDescription.name: value
featureDescription.description: The field value.

featureDescription.name: name
featureDescription.description: The name of the tag.

featureDescription.name: layer
featureDescription.description: The layer to which the tagset applies. This is typically the name of an UIMA type such as "de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.lexmorph.type.pos.POS".

featureDescription.name: name
featureDescription.description: The name of the tagset.

featureDescription.name: tags
featureDescription.description: Descriptions of the tags belonging to this tagset.

featureDescription.name: input
featureDescription.description: True if the tagset is used as input by the component/model, otherwise false.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.ner.type.NamedEntity
typeDescription.description: Named entities refer e.g. to persons, locations, organizations and so on. They often consist of multiple tokens.

featureDescription.name: value
featureDescription.description: The class/category of the named entity, e.g. person, location, etc.

featureDescription.name: identifier
featureDescription.description: Identifier of the named entity, e.g. a reference into a person database.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.phonetics.type.PhoneticTranscription
typeDescription.description: Represents the phonetic transcription of some textual element (usually a Token). Phonetic transcriptions are e.g. generated by transcription processes like Soundex or Metaphone.

featureDescription.name: transcription
featureDescription.description: The actual transcription

featureDescription.name: name
featureDescription.description: The name of the transcription process that was used

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.segmentation.type.Compound
typeDescription.description: This type represents a decompounding word, i.e.: flowerpot. Each Compound one have at least two Splits.

featureDescription.name: splits
featureDescription.description: A word that can be decomposed into different parts.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.segmentation.type.CompoundPart
typeDescription.description: A CompoundPart represents one fragment from the compounding word. Besides that, it can store other CompoundParts if it can be split again. The way it stores a decompounding word represents a decompounding tree.

featureDescription.name: id
featureDescription.description: If this unit had an ID in the source format from which it was imported, it may be stored here. IDs are typically not assigned by DKPro Core components. If an ID is present, it should be respected by writers.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.segmentation.type.LinkingMorpheme
typeDescription.description: This type represents a linking morpheme between two CompoundParts.

featureDescription.name: id
featureDescription.description: If this unit had an ID in the source format from which it was imported, it may be stored here. IDs are typically not assigned by DKPro Core components. If an ID is present, it should be respected by writers.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.segmentation.type.Split
typeDescription.description: This type represents a part of a decompounding word. A Split can be either a CompoundPart or a LinkingMorpheme.

featureDescription.name: splits
featureDescription.description: Sub-splits of the current split.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.segmentation.type.SurfaceForm
typeDescription.description: This annotation can be used to indicate an alternate surface form. E.g. some corpora consider a normalized form of the text with resolved contractions as the canonical form and only maintain the original surface form as a secondary information. One example is the Conll-U format.

featureDescription.name: value
featureDescription.description: Alternate surface form.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.segmentation.type.Token
typeDescription.description: Token is one of the two types commonly produced by a segmenter (the other being Sentence). A Token usually represents a word, although it may be used to represent multiple tightly connected words (e.g. "New York") or parts of a word (e.g. the possessive "'s"). One may choose to split compound words into multiple tokens, e.g. ("CamelCase" -> "Camel", "Case"; "Zauberstab" -> "Zauber", "stab"). Most processing components operate on Tokens, usually within the limits of the surrounding Sentence. E.g. a part-of-speech tagger analyses each Token in a Sentence and assigns a part-of-speech to each Token.

featureDescription.name: parent
featureDescription.description: the parent of this token. This feature is meant to be used in when the token participates in a constituency parse and then refers to a constituent containing this token. The type of this feature is {@link Annotation} to avoid adding a dependency on the syntax API module.

featureDescription.name: morph
featureDescription.description: The morphological feature associated with this token.

featureDescription.name: id
featureDescription.description: If this unit had an ID in the source format from which it was imported, it may be stored here. IDs are typically not assigned by DKPro Core components. If an ID is present, it should be respected by writers.

featureDescription.name: form
featureDescription.description: Potentially normalized form of the token text that should be used instead of the covered text if set.

featureDescription.name: order
featureDescription.description: Disambiguates the token order for tokens which have the same offsets, e.g. when the contraction "Ã " is analyzed as two tokens "a" and "a".

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.segmentation.type.TokenForm
typeDescription.description: A alternative token text which should be used instead of the covered text if set on a token.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.semantics.type.SemArg
typeDescription.description: The SemArg annotation is attached to semantic arguments of semantic predicates. Semantic arguments are characterized by their semantic role, e.g. Agent, Experiencer, Topic. The semantic role of an argument is related to its semantic type (for communication verbs, the Agent can be a person or an organization, but typically not food).

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.semantics.type.SemArgLink
typeDescription.description: The SemArgLink type is used to attach SemPred annotations to their respective SemArg annotations while giving each link a role.

featureDescription.name: role
featureDescription.description: The role which the argument takes. The value depends on the theory being used, e.g. Arg0, Arg1, etc. or Buyer, Seller, etc.

featureDescription.name: target
featureDescription.description: The target argument.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.semantics.type.SemPred
typeDescription.description: One of the predicates of a sentence (often a main verb, but nouns and adjectives can also be predicates). The SemPred annotation can be attached to predicates in a sentence. Semantic predicates express events or situations and take semantic arguments expressing the participants in these events or situations. All forms of main verbs can be annotated with a SemPred. However, there are also many nouns and adjectives that take arguments and can thus be annotated with a SemanticPredicate, e.g. event nouns, such as "suggestion" (with arguments what and by whom), or relational adjectives, such as "proud" (with arguments who and of what).

featureDescription.name: arguments
featureDescription.description: The predicate's arguments.

featureDescription.name: category
featureDescription.description: A more detailed specification of the predicate type depending on the theory being used, e.g. a frame name.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.semantics.type.SemanticArgument
typeDescription.description:
The SemanticArgument annotation is attached to semantic arguments of semantic predicates. Semantic arguments are characterized by their semantic role, e.g. Agent, Experiencer, Topic. The semantic role of an argument is related to its semantic type (for communication verbs, the Agent can be a person or an organization, but typically not food). The semantic type of arguments is not yet covered by the SemanticType.
@deprecated Use SemArg instead.

featureDescription.name: role
featureDescription.description: The role which the argument takes. The value depends on the theory being used, e.g. Arg0, Arg1, etc. or Buyer, Seller, etc.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.semantics.type.SemanticField
typeDescription.description: The SemanticField is a coarse-grained semantic category that can be attached to nouns, verbs or adjectives. Semantic field information is present e.g. in WordNet as lexicographer file names. Previously, this kind of semantic information has also been called supersenses or semantic types.

featureDescription.name: value
featureDescription.description: The value or name of the semantic field. Examples of semantic field values are: location, artifact, event, communication, attribute

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.semantics.type.SemanticPredicate
typeDescription.description:
One of the predicates of a sentence (often a main verb, but nouns and adjectives can also be predicates). The SemanticPredicate annotation can be attached to predicates in a sentence. Semantic predicates express events or situations and take semantic arguments expressing the participants in these events ore situations. All forms of main verbs can be annotated with a SemanticPredicate. However, there are also many nouns and adjectives that take arguments and can thus be annotated with a SemanticPredicate, e.g. event nouns, such as "suggestion" (with arguments what and by whom), or relational adjectives, such as "proud" (with arguments who and of what).
@deprecated use SemPred instead

featureDescription.name: category
featureDescription.description: A more detailed specification of the predicate type depending on the theory being used, e.g. a frame name.

featureDescription.name: arguments
featureDescription.description: The predicate's arguments.

featureDescription.name: value
featureDescription.description: The sense identifier.

featureDescription.name: name
featureDescription.description: the name of the tag

featureDescription.name: PennTree
featureDescription.description: Contains a Penn Treebank-style representation of a tree.

featureDescription.name: TransformationNames
featureDescription.description: The name(s) of the transformation(s) that have been performed on the PennTree

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.syntax.type.chunk.CONCJ
typeDescription.description: complex coordinating conjunctions such as "as well (as)" or "rather (than)"

featureDescription.name: parent
featureDescription.description: The parent constituent

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.syntax.type.constituent.PARN
typeDescription.description: This cateory is called PRN in the Penn Treebank tagset. However, PRN is a reserved device name on Window. Thus we had to rename this category. The old PRN type is still present in the DKPro Core type system, but it is deprecated, no longer used, and no JCas classes are generated for it.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.syntax.type.dependency.Dependency
typeDescription.description: A dependency relation between two tokens. The dependency annotation begin and end offsets correspond to those of the dependent.

featureDescription.name: Governor
featureDescription.description: The governor word

featureDescription.name: Dependent
featureDescription.description: The dependent word

featureDescription.name: DependencyType
featureDescription.description: The dependency type

featureDescription.name: flavor
featureDescription.description: Flavor of the dependency relation (basic, collapsed, enhanced, etc...)

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.transform.type.SofaChangeAnnotation
typeDescription.description: Encodes an edit operation that can be interpreted by the ApplyChangesAnnotator.

featureDescription.name: value
featureDescription.description: In case of an "insert" or "replace" operation, this feature indicates the value to be inserted or replaced.

featureDescription.name: operation
featureDescription.description: Operation to perform: "insert", "replace", "delete"

featureDescription.name: reason
featureDescription.description: The reason for the change.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.io.jwpl.type.ArticleInfo
typeDescription.description: Contains basic information about the article.

featureDescription.name: Authors
featureDescription.description: Number of unique authors of this article

featureDescription.name: Revisions
featureDescription.description: Number of revisions of this article.

featureDescription.name: FirstAppearance
featureDescription.description: The Timestamp of the first appearance of this article.

featureDescription.name: LastAppearance
featureDescription.description: The Timestamp of the last appearance of this article.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.io.jwpl.type.DBConfig
typeDescription.description: Database configuration for the connection to the database where the CAS data was retrieved.

featureDescription.name: Host
featureDescription.description: DB Host

featureDescription.name: DB
featureDescription.description: Database

featureDescription.name: User
featureDescription.description: Username

featureDescription.name: Password
featureDescription.description: User password

featureDescription.name: Language
featureDescription.description: Wikipedia Language Versions

featureDescription.name: LinkType
featureDescription.description: The type of the link, e.g. internal, external, image, ...

featureDescription.name: Target
featureDescription.description: The link target url

featureDescription.name: Anchor
featureDescription.description: The anchor of the link

featureDescription.name: revisionId
featureDescription.description: The ID of the revision.

featureDescription.name: pageId
featureDescription.description: The pageId of the Wikipedia page of this revision.

featureDescription.name: contributorName
featureDescription.description: The username of the user/contributor who edited this revision.

featureDescription.name: comment
featureDescription.description: The comment that the editor entered for this revision.

featureDescription.name: contributorId
featureDescription.description: The userId of the user/contributor who created this revision

featureDescription.name: timestamp
featureDescription.description: The timestamp of the revision, given in milliseconds since the standard base time (January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT)

featureDescription.name: minor
featureDescription.description: Whether this revision has been marked as minor edit by its contributor.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.mallet.type.TopicDistribution
typeDescription.description: An array representing the topic proportions in a document.

featureDescription.name: TopicProportions
featureDescription.description: Each topic's proportion in the document.

featureDescription.name: TopicAssignment
featureDescription.description: Pointers to topics the document has been assigned to.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.mallet.type.WordEmbedding
typeDescription.description: An array representing the word embedding vector.

featureDescription.name: WordEmbedding
featureDescription.description: A word embedding vector.

featureDescription.name: dan
featureDescription.description: Specifies the kind of the verb if the current token is a verb. Either it is a vowel stem verb (ichi-dan) or a consonant stem verb (go-dan). Blank if not a verb.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.performance.type.TimerAnnotation
typeDescription.description: Used for storing timing information (e.g. for performance testing).

featureDescription.name: name
featureDescription.description: The name of the timer. Used to automatically determine whether this is an upstream or downstream timer.

featureDescription.name: uri
featureDescription.description: Namespace URI of the attribute.

featureDescription.name: localName
featureDescription.description: Local name of the attribute.

featureDescription.name: value
featureDescription.description: Value of the XML attribute.

featureDescription.name: root
featureDescription.description: Root element of the XML document.

featureDescription.name: uri
featureDescription.description: Namespace URI of the element.

featureDescription.name: localName
featureDescription.description: Local name of the XML element.

featureDescription.name: attributes
featureDescription.description: Array of attributes of the XML element.

featureDescription.name: children
featureDescription.description: Children of this XML element.

featureDescription.name: captured
featureDescription.description: Whether the text node has been added to the document text.

typeDescription.name: org.dkpro.core.io.nift.metadata.ArticleMetaData
typeDescription.description: A document annotation that describes the metadata of a newspaper article.

featureDescription.name: guid
featureDescription.description: The GUID field specifies a (4-byte) integer that is guaranteed to be unique for every document in the corpus.

featureDescription.name: alternateUrl
featureDescription.description: This field specifies the location on nytimes.com of the article. When present, this URL is preferred to the URL field on articles published on or after April 02, 2006, as the linked page will have richer content.

featureDescription.name: url
featureDescription.description: This field specifies the location on nytimes.com of the article. The 'Alternative Url' field is preferred to this field on articles published on or after April 02, 2006, as the linked page will have richer content.

featureDescription.name: publicationDate
featureDescription.description: This field specifies the date of the article's publication. This field is specified in the format YYYYMMDD'T'HHMMSS where: 1. YYYY is the four-digit year. 2. MM is the two-digit month [01-12]. 3. DD is the two-digit day [01-31]. 4. T is a constant value. 5. HH is the two-digit hour [00-23]. 6. MM is the two-digit minute-past-the hour [00-59] 7. SS is the two-digit seconds-past-the-minute [00-59]. Please note that values for HH,MM, and SS are not defined for this corpus, that is to day HH,MM, and SS are always defined to be '00'.

featureDescription.name: typesOfMaterial
featureDescription.description: This field specifies a normalized list of terms describing the general editorial category of the article. These tags are algorithmically assigned and manually verified by nytimes.com production staff. Examples Include: * REVIEW * OBITUARY * ANALYSIS

featureDescription.name: headline
featureDescription.description: This field specifies the headline of the article as it appeared in the print edition of the New York Times.

featureDescription.name: onlineHeadline
featureDescription.description: This field specifies the headline displayed with the article on nytimes.com. Often this differs from the headline used in print.

featureDescription.name: columnName
featureDescription.description: If the article is part of a regular column, this field specifies the name of that column. Sample Column Names: 1. World News Briefs 2. WEDDINGS 3. The Accessories Channel

featureDescription.name: author
featureDescription.description: This field is based on the normalized byline in the original corpus data: "The Normalized Byline field is the byline normalized to the form (last name, first name)".

featureDescription.name: descriptors
featureDescription.description: The 'descriptors' field specifies a list of descriptive terms drawn from a normalized controlled vocabulary corresponding to subjects mentioned in the article. These tags are hand-assigned by a team of library scientists working in the New York Times Indexing service. Examples Include: * ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND TRENDS * AIRPLANES * VIOLINS

featureDescription.name: onlineDescriptors
featureDescription.description: This field specifies a list of descriptors from a normalized controlled vocabulary that correspond to topics mentioned in the article. These tags are algorithmically assigned and manually verified by nytimes.com production staff. Examples Include: * Marriages * Parks and Other Recreation Areas * Cooking and Cookbooks

featureDescription.name: generalOnlineDescriptors
featureDescription.description: The 'general online descriptors' field specifies a list of descriptors that are at a higher level of generality than the other tags associated with the article. These tags are algorithmically assigned and manually verified by nytimes.com production staff. Examples Include: * Surfing * Venice Biennale * Ranches

featureDescription.name: onlineSection
featureDescription.description: This field specifies the section(s) on nytimes.com in which the article is placed. If the article is placed in multiple sections, this field will be specified as a ';' delineated list.

featureDescription.name: section
featureDescription.description: This field specifies the section of the paper in which the article appears. This is not the name of the section, but rather a letter or number that indicates the section.

featureDescription.name: taxonomicClassifiers
featureDescription.description: This field specifies a list of taxonomic classifiers that place this article into a hierarchy of articles. The individual terms of each taxonomic classifier are separated with the '/' character. These tags are algorithmically assigned and manually verified by nytimes.com production staff. Examples Include: * Top/Features/Travel/Guides/Destinations/North America/United States/Arizona * Top/News/U.S./Rockies * Top/Opinion
